Award.AwardTitle: Development of functional polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program in the Division of Chemistry, Qian Wang of the University of South Carolina will develop a new strategy to synthesize functional polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles. Specifically, the project will focus on the design and synthesis of biocompatible and biodegradable polymers for the fabrication of polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles. The assembly process will be characterized quantitatively using solution small angle neutron scattering, fluorescent microscopy, isothermal titration calorimetry and quartz crystal microbalance techniques. Finally, in order to validate the synthetic chemistry, a model core-shell nanoparticle system will be created for delivery and release of a molecular payload. The broader impacts of the project involve the interdisciplinary training of project participants, ranging from high school students to undergraduate and graduate students. The project will enable them to develop advanced research skills and provide international networks that will serve students well in their future careers under the ever-growing situation of economic globalization.

This research project will uncover new ways to create small particles with nanometer dimensions that are hybrids of synthetic materials and proteins. Such knowledge is essential for the development of low-cost, structurally well-defined particles that could be used for applications ranging from drug delivery, to protein pharmaceuticals, and to the stabilization and support of enzyme catalysts.

Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins serve as critical functional biomacromolecules in biomedical applications. Funded by NSF Award, our project developed a novel and robust method to produce polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles. As shown in the figure, different proteins can assemble with easy available polymers without losing the folding structures and functional activities. Here are some key outcomes:

(1) We found that protein and protein nanoparticles can assemble with pyridine-grafted polymers, forming structurally well-defined core-shell nanoparticles.

(2) We found that the assembly between proteins and polymers is driven by displacing proteins (serving as amphiphiles) at the interface of aqueous phase and polymer to minimize the interfacial energy.

(3) A number of novel polymers have been synthesized with good biocompatibility.

(4) Model protein-polymer assembled systems have been produced for targeted drug delivery applications.

(5) We have characterized the structures of artificial multi-component assemblies and investigated the interaction, catalysis and diffusion behavior of multi-enzyme complexes.

We anticipate that our results can provide novel insights for the development of low-cost, structurally well-defined nanoassemblies for applications in drug delivery, protein pharmaceuticals, antigen preservation, and multi-enzyme reactors for cascade catalysis, etc. In addition, our results offer some fundamentals in understanding the adsorption/desorption, assembly and confinement of bio-macromolecules at the micro- and nano-interfaces. Such knowledge is essential for developing novel biomaterials and biopharmaceuticals. As a good example, during our study, we have demonstrated the feasibility of the assembly of pathogenic proteins with biodegradable polymers, which can potentially be used in vaccine development.

The interdisciplinary feature of this proposed research helped us to recruit and train multilevel participants – ranging from high school students to undergraduate and graduate students. This project is truly interdisciplinary. Students worked in this project have chance to learn polymer synthesis, protein expression and purification, bioconjugation chemistry, materials science, self-assembly, drug delivery and in vivo animal studies. Also, they are exposed to many equipments and instrumental analysis techniques, such as MALDI MS, transmission electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, fluorimeter, UV-vis spectrometer, circular dichroism, NMR, protein electrophoresis, confocal microscopy, cell culturing, real time PCR, FACS, and Western Blot technology etc. Finally, students are involved in multiple collaborative research activities internationally.

Overall 5 undergraduate students, 6 graduate students (5 female) and 3 postdoctoral fellows have been involved in this project. We successfully created a multifaceted collaborative research framework among University of South Carolina, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry (China), Georgia Institute of Technology, Chulalongkorn University (Thailand), and NanoGune Institute (Spain). In addition, the PI has organized a special symposium in the 2016 Spring ACS meeting in San Diego, 2017 Fall ACS meeting in Washington D.C. and 2016 SERMCS, with the theme of “protein based biomaterials”. In addition, 20 peer reviewed publications have been published supported by this NSF award. The PI and his students have successfully disseminated their discoveries in more than 30 lectures and presentations.


Last Modified: 11/17/2017
Modified by: Qian Wang

  • We have developed of low-cost, structurally well-defined nanoassemblies from functional proteins and polymers, which can potentially be applied for drug delivery, protein pharmaceuticals, antigen preservation, and multi-enzyme reactors for cascade catalysis, etc.

    Qian Wang
    Assembly of polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles

Funded by NSF Award, our project developed a novel and robust method to produce polymer-protein core-shell nanoparticles.
